title: Ulysses Grant-Smith
text:
Ulysses S. Grant-Smith (November 18, 1870 – August 27, 1959) was an American career diplomat who served as <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20Albania">Minister to Albania</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20Uruguay">Minister to Uruguay</a> during the interwar period.
Biography.
He was originally from <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Washington County, Pennsylvania</a>. A career <a href="foreign%20service%20officer">foreign service officer</a>, he began serving as a diplomat in 1903, and arrived in Copenhagen on 18 July 1917, to take up the position of Counselor at the US Legation there. Less than five months later, upon Minister <a href="Maurice%20Francis%20Egan">Maurice Egan's</a> departure on 16 December, he became Chargé d'Affaires and the ranking US representative in Denmark. He remained Chargé for over a year, until the arrival of the new US Minister, <a href="Norman%20Hapgood">Norman Hapgood</a>, on April 16, 1919. On September 18, 1919, Grant-Smith left Copenhagen, and was declared eligible for a new diplomatic assignment. On December 4, 1919, he was appointed US Commissioner to Hungary, signing the <a href="U.S.%E2%80%93Hungarian%20Peace%20Treaty%20%281921%29">U.S.-Hungarian Peace Treaty</a> in 1921. In 1922, he became the first U.S. Minister to <a href="Albania">Albania</a>. Grant-Smith was appointed to the post in September 1922 by President <a href="Warren%20G.%20Harding">Warren G. Harding</a>, and arrived in <a href="Tirana">Tirana</a> in December of the same year. He served through February 8, 1925, and was then made Minister to <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> from 1925 to 1929.
Ulysses Grant-Smith died on August 27, 1959, at the home of his niece, in <a href="Washington%2C%20Pennsylvania">Washington, Pennsylvania</a>.
